sec.title: Case Presentation
sec.p: An 8-month-old boy was referred to the pediatric dermatology clinic from his primary care physician for hair loss. According to his mother, the boy was born with a full head of hair but without eyebrows or eyelashes. At around 2 to 3 weeks old, he began losing his hair circumferentially around the sides and back of his head. At his first clinic evaluation, the areas on his head as well as his eyebrows were completely hairless, but he had sparse small eyelashes. His mother reported no pruritus or any indication of irritation or tenderness. He received clobetasol scalp solution for presumed alopecia areata with ophiasis presentation and was asked to follow up in a few weeks. On return 1 month later, he had no new hair growth or loss. Additionally, his mother reported that he had developed asymptomatic “bumpy” skin around his nose and on his extremities. He was otherwise healthy and was developing normally after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He had appropriate teeth and nail development for his age and had no known sweating or hearing abnormalities. There was also no known family history of skin disease, hair loss, or autoimmune conditions. Further questioning by genetics revealed consanguinity.

Clinical examination revealed a well-demarcated nonscarring alopecia involving the occipitoparietal region in an ophiasis pattern as well as the temporal regions in an androgenic pattern (Figure 1). A hair pull test around the vertex and frontal areas was negative. Eyebrows were completely absent and there were small eyelashes noted. He had tiny milia-like follicular papules on the upper outer arms, thighs, knees, and facial cheeks (Figure 2). A biopsy was not performed.

caption.p: Well-demarcated, nonscarring alopecia involving the occipitoparietal and temporal regions. There is also an absence of eyebrows and minimal eyelash growth
On the cheeks, upper outer arms, thighs, and knees are tiny milia-like follicular papules

sec.title: Hospital Course
sec.p: After receiving a clinical diagnosis of atrichia with papular lesions (APL), the steroid scalp solution was discontinued and ammonium lactate cream was prescribed for the papular lesions. The family was counseled about genetic testing to look for a causative mutation in the associated gene, human homolog of the mouse “hairless” (HR) gene, which was available on a research basis. They met with a genetic counselor and agreed to send blood for genotyping to Columbia University. Almost a year and a half later, his scalp, eyelash, and eyebrow alopecia was unchanged. DNA sequencing analysis at Columbia identified a homozygous mutation within exon 2 of the HR gene, called R33X, confirming the diagnosis of APL.

sec.title: Clinical Findings in APL
sec.p: Atrichia with papular lesions (papular atrichia, OMIM 209500) is a rare, autosomal recessive genodermatosis characterized by irreversible loss of head and body hair and the development of keratin-filled cysts on the body. Affected individuals are typically born with normal appearing neonatal hair, which is gradually lost and never replaced by adult terminal hair. Hair is typically absent from the scalp, axillae, and body although some small eyebrows or eyelashes may be present. The papular lesions usually develop around 1 to 2 years of age but can arise at any time within the first decade of life.1 They most commonly involve the face, scalp, and extremities, particularly the elbows and knees, and they tend to increase in number as the individual ages.2 Individuals with APL have otherwise normal development, including teeth, hair, sweating, and hearing, which importantly distinguishes the disease from ectodermal dysplasia with associated atrichia. Histopathologic examination reveals empty infundibulae with irregular epithelial structures or cysts replacing the lower two thirds of hair follicles and various sizes of keratinizing epithelial cysts at all levels of the dermis.3

The diagnostic criteria for APL were updated in 2008 by Yip et al4 based on a literature review and personal observations. The authors recommend that 4 of 5 major criteria to be present for diagnosis and also provide 5 supplementary minor criteria. The major criteria include infantile atrichia, development of characteristic papular lesions, histological scalp findings, HR gene mutation, and clinical and/or molecular exclusion of vitamin D–dependent rickets (VDDR), specifically type II. VDDR-II is caused by a mutation in the vitamin D receptor, which renders it resistant to vitamin D3. Some patients with VDDR-II have alopecia that is clinically and microscopically similar to APL in addition to their findings of vitamin D deficiency such as early-onset rickets, hypocalcemia, and secondary hyperparathyroidism. The diseases likely share a common pathogenic pathway with regard to follicular development.3,5 The minor criteria that support the diagnosis include a family history of consanguinity, absence of other body hair, whitish hypopigmented streaks on the scalp, normal growth and development, and lack of response to any treatment modality. It is important to note that a scalp biopsy is not required for a diagnosis when clinical and genetic findings support APL.

sec.title: Molecular Basis of APL
sec.p: Mutations in the human homolog of the mouse “hairless” (HR) gene have been implicated in the development of APL. Mutations in the HR gene are also responsible for another genetic cause of hair loss, alopecia universalis congenital, which is clinically distinguished by the absence of papular lesions. The HR gene is found on chromosome 8p21.2 and encodes a single zinc-finger transcription factor, which is highly expressed in the brain and skin.6 The HR protein functions as a co-repressor of multiple nuclear receptors, including the vitamin-D receptor (VDR). It has been hypothesized that VDR-HR suppresses gene expression during specific phases of the hair cycle. With loss of this repressive activity, there is inappropriate expression of genes that disrupt the normal hair cycle process.7 Histologically, the process is seen as a disintegration of the lower two thirds of the hair follicle which results in failure to enter anagen phase. Remnant structures are likely responsible for producing the characteristic epithelial outgrowths and dermal cysts.3

The database of allelic series continues to expand as more than 30 different nonsense, missense, insertion, and deletion mutations have been reported in the HR gene.4,8 Although the majority of cases of APL involve homozygous mutations, sporadic cases of compound heterozygous mutations in nonconsanguineous families have been identified over the past decade.1,4,9-12

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It is important to consider APL when a newborn or infant presents with hair loss. Although alopecia totalis caused by autoimmune destruction of the follicle is a more common cause of hair loss, APL should not be overlooked in the differential diagnosis. Prompt diagnosis will prevent the child from undergoing invasive diagnostic procedures and unnecessary treatments for autoimmune alopecia. Genetic counseling is also beneficial for patient understanding of inheritance patterns and disease etiology.
